title: Live updates: Israeli strikes could cause regime change in Iran, Netanyahu says; Iran fires more missiles at Israel
description: “The Iran regime is very weak,” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a television interview. Israeli struck energy facilities and government buildings Sunday.
author: Andrew Jeong, Abbie Cheeseman, Sammy Westfall, Yeganeh Torbati
byline: Andrew Jeong, Abbie Cheeseman, Sammy Westfall, Yeganeh Torbati, Susannah George, Gerry Shih, Erin Cunningham, Shira Rubin, Mustafa Salim, Lior Soroka, Daniel Wu, Mariana Alfaro, Meryl Kornfield, Jintak Han, Heidi Levine, Michael Birnbaum, Mikhail Klimentov
excerpt: “The Iran regime is very weak,” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a television interview. Israeli struck energy facilities and government buildings Sunday.
text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that regime change in Iran “could certainly be the result” of Israel’s military campaign. “Because the Iran regime is very weak,” he said in an interview with Fox News. Israeli strikes hit a wide array of targets across Iran on Sunday, the third day of the offensive, including energy facilities and government buildings in Tehran, prompting some residents to flee the capital. Later, Iran fired another round of ballistic missiles at Israel, hitting at least one town in the south and the key port city of Haifa in the north. The attacks by Israel have killed more than 200 people in Iran, Iranian media reported, quoting a health ministry spokesman. When asked late Sunday how he plans to de-escalate the situation, President Donald Trump said, “sometimes they have to fight it out.”Live coverage contributors 17Israel takes aim at Iran’s government with expanded targetsReturn to menuIsraeli strikes targeting Iranian energy production facilities, manufacturing plants and aviation signaled the start of a wider and more intense phase of the conflict Sunday, as Israeli war planes pursued new targets deeper in Iran’s cities and towns.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuAt least 224 people have been killed in Iran since Israel began bombing the country on Friday, local media reported, quoting health ministry spokesman Hossein Kermanpour. In a statement, he said more than 1,200 people have been hospitalized and that the majority of the wounded so far are civilians.Clash with Iran boosts Netanyahu, but Israelis worry about long fightReturn to menuTEL AVIV — Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s shaky political position may have been solidified by Israel’s campaign against Iran’s nuclear facilities and its leadership, but to sustain public support he needs to show the military operation is a success and ensure it doesn’t become a protracted conflict, analysts say.This is an excerpt from a full story.Israeli strike kills Revolutionary Guard intelligence chief in TehranReturn to menuAn Israeli strike in Tehran killed the intelligence chief of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, the organization said in a statement Sunday, the latest senior military official to be eliminated in Israel’s wide-ranging military campaign.Brig. Gen. Mohammad Kazemi was killed along with two other deputies, the statement said, adding that Iran’s barrage of missiles fired at Israel late Sunday was launched in part to avenge his death.Iranian missiles cause damage, injuries in northern and southern IsraelReturn to menuIran launched a barrage of missiles toward Israel on Sunday night, some of which were intercepted while others hit northern Israel, leaving several people with minor injuries. Projectile debris also fell on a residential community near the city of Kiryat Gat in Israel’s south.Return to menuIsrael on Sunday approved the extension of a nationwide state of emergency until June 30, according to an Israeli official speaking on the condition of anonymity in line with government protocol. Israel’s Home Front Command also announced that school would be canceled and said people should not go to the office or gather together until Tuesday evening.Netanyahu says regime change could be result of Israeli strikes on IranReturn to menuIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that regime change in Iran “could certainly be the result” of Israel’s military campaign.Netanyahu made the remarks on “Fox News Sunday” after anchor Bret Baier asked if “regime change” was one of Israel’s objectives. “Clearly, some of these strikes have targeted Iranian leadership, military, nuclear scientists. … So, is regime change part of the effort here?” Baier said.Return to menuThe U.S. Embassy in Baghdad issued a security alert Sunday saying it was “aware of the increased potential for foreign terrorist organization-inspired violence or attacks against U.S. businesses and locations frequented by U.S. citizens.” The Embassy urged all U.S. citizens in Iraq to avoid such locations and large crowds. Israeli air force struck Iranian aircraft in northeastern Iran, IDF saysReturn to menuThe Israeli air force struck an Iranian aerial refueling aircraft at Mashhad Airport in northeastern Iran, Israel Defense Forces spokesperson Nadav Shoshani said on X on Sunday.Mashhad is a major city that’s almost 1,500 miles from Tel Aviv. Shoshani said the attack was “the longest-range strike conducted since the beginning of the operation.”Return to menuIsraeli military spokesman Nadav Shoshani said Sunday that Israel’s goal “is not a change of regime” in Iran. He said the objective is to “remove the capabilities of this regime to annihilate us,” including Iran’s nuclear program and arsenal of ballistic missiles.‘Everyone is really worried,’ Tehran residents feel fear, confusion on third day of strikesReturn to menuIman, a resident of Tehran, said the city was being hit with strikes on Sunday every 30 minutes to an hour. “The racket and noise is really a lot now,” he said.The city was mostly quiet except for people rushing to get needed food and supplies. Gas stations have been packed with people trying to fuel up, and at least some stations were starting to ration fuel to customers.Return to menuSen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) told CBS News on Sunday that, if diplomacy is not successful, he would urge President Trump to “go all in to make sure that when this operation is over, there’s nothing left standing in Iran regarding their nuclear program."“If that means providing bombs ... if it means flying with Israel, fly with Israel,” he said.Return to menuMichael Leiter, the Israeli ambassador to the United States, told ABC News on Sunday that Israel’s target list includes anyone “threatening the destruction” of the country. “The idea is to neutralize and terminate the Iranian intention of destroying Israel through nuclear weapons and through ballistic missiles, and anybody who gets in the way of that … is obviously somebody we’re going to have to deal with,” he said.Pence warns Trump against Putin’s advice on Israel-IranReturn to menuFormer vice president Mike Pence warned President Donald Trump on Sunday to steer clear of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s involvement in the response to the Israel-Iran conflict, after Trump and Putin spoke on Saturday.“I would say respectfully to the administration, we ought to be looking elsewhere than Vladimir Putin for advice on how to deal with this situation,” Pence said on CNN’s “State of the Union.” Pence was vice president during Trump’s first term.Return to menuOne Tehran resident said that he told his employees to go home around midday on Sunday, advising them to leave the city, and that most private firms are shutting down. “It’s a total war now,” he said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to avoid government reprisal.Return to menuThe barrage of strikes hitting Iran and Israel is continuing. Residents in Tehran and Iranian media reported large explosions rocking the capital in the past hour, including in parts of the city center. Within minutes, the Israel Defense Forces warned Israeli citizens to stay near shelters, and sirens alerted in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and northern Israel as the military identified missiles launched from Iran.Return to menuKataib Hezbollah, an Iranian-aligned militant group in Iraq, said Sunday that if Washington “intervenes” in the Israel-Iran conflict, it will target U.S. bases and military assets across the Mideast “without hesitation.” Aside from Yemen’s Houthis, who launched a ballistic missile toward Israel on Saturday “in coordination” with Iranian attacks, Tehran’s proxy forces have not jumped into the fray in the conflict’s initial days.Israel has many targets left to strike in Iran, military official saysReturn to menuBEIRUT — Israel maintains a large bank of target sites in Iran, an Israeli military official told reporters Sunday, as deadly strikes between the two countries continued into a third day.The military official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity in line with military rules, declined to say how many targets remained or to give a timeline for the attacks, as fears grow of a protracted conflict that could risk a wider regional war.Return to menuTEL AVIV — Israeli and Iranian airspace will remain closed for a third day, authorities in both countries said, with some flights across the Mideast disrupted because of the risk of a regional conflagration. Israel’s National Security Council has also warned people against returning to Israel via land borders in Egypt and Jordan because of security risks there.Iran doesn’t want conflict to spread ‘unless it is imposed on us,’ top diplomat saysReturn to menuBEIRUT — If Israeli attacks on Iran stop, “our responses will stop,” Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi told diplomats in a televised briefing Sunday, adding that Tehran doesn’t want strikes to spread to neighboring countries “unless it is imposed on us.”Return to menuIran arrested two people Sunday whom it accused of having ties to the Mossad, Israel’s intelligence agency, in the Alborz province, west of Tehran, the semiofficial Tasnim news agency reported. They were accused of “making bombs, explosives, booby traps and electronic equipment,” the report said, citing a police spokesperson.Return to menuPhotos show Iran’s Shahran oil depot was engulfed in a massive fireball and plumes of smoke following overnight Israeli strikes on the Iranian capital of Tehran early Sunday.Return to menuThe Israeli military issued its first evacuation warning for Iranian civilians nationwide who may be near “military weapons production sites,” now or in the near future, as the region braces for a protracted conflict. The warning, posted on X Sunday morning by a military spokesperson, has routinely signaled in conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon that fresh rounds of Israeli strikes are coming.Return to menuFour people were killed Saturday in a rocket strike in northern Israel, according to a local health official and Magen David Adom, Israel’s emergency services. The bodies of two women were found at a destroyed building in the western Galilee region, MDA said. Another woman in critical condition was evacuated from the building but was pronounced dead at a hospital. A fourth woman died at the Rambam medical center in Haifa from injuries sustained during the strike, the center’s spokesman said.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump said on Truth Social that the United States was not involved in Israel’s attacks on Iran overnight, and warned that Iran will face “the full strength and might” of the U.S. military if it attacks the U.S. “in any way.” Trump also said his administration could “easily get a deal done” between Israel and Iran.In ordering major attack on Iran, Netanyahu sheds his inhibitionsReturn to menuJERUSALEM — Although the outcome of hostilities that erupted this week between Israel and Iran remains uncertain, the scale and audacity of Israel’s airstrikes have made one thing clear: Inhibitions that may have constrained Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the past no longer do so.This is an excerpt from a full story.At least six dead in strike on Bat Yam, Israel, authorities sayReturn to menuBAT YAM, Israel — A strike here Sunday killed at least six people and injured dozens more, according to the Israeli prime minister’s office.Two women, a boy and a girl were among the dead, Magen David Adom, Israel’s emergency services said in a statement. At least 99 people were injured in the attack, it said, with four in serious condition.U.S. hopes Iran returns to negotiations, U.S. officials sayReturn to menuDespite the fighting between Israel and Iran, the United States remains committed to negotiations and hopes Iran “will come to the table soon,” said one senior U.S. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive negotiations.That sentiment was echoed in a White House statement calling on Iran to give up its nuclear weapons program.
html:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that regime change in Iran “could certainly be the result” of Israel’s military campaign. “Because the Iran regime is very weak,” he said in an interview with Fox News. Israeli strikes hit a wide array of targets across Iran on Sunday, the third day of the offensive, including energy facilities and government buildings in Tehran, prompting some residents to flee the capital. Later, Iran fired another round of ballistic missiles at Israel, hitting at least one town in the south and the key port city of Haifa in the north. The attacks by Israel have killed more than 200 people in Iran, Iranian media reported, quoting a health ministry spokesman. When asked late Sunday how he plans to de-escalate the situation, President Donald Trump said, “sometimes they have to fight it out.”

Live coverage contributors 17

  • Israel takes aim at Iran’s government with expanded targets

    Return to menu

    Israeli strikes targeting Iranian energy production facilities, manufacturing plants and aviation signaled the start of a wider and more intense phase of the conflict Sunday, as Israeli war planes pursued new targets deeper in Iran’s cities and towns.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    At least 224 people have been killed in Iran since Israel began bombing the country on Friday, local media reported, quoting health ministry spokesman Hossein Kermanpour. In a statement, he said more than 1,200 people have been hospitalized and that the majority of the wounded so far are civilians.

  • Clash with Iran boosts Netanyahu, but Israelis worry about long fight

    Return to menu

    TEL AVIV — Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s shaky political position may have been solidified by Israel’s campaign against Iran’s nuclear facilities and its leadership, but to sustain public support he needs to show the military operation is a success and ensure it doesn’t become a protracted conflict, analysts say.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Israeli strike kills Revolutionary Guard intelligence chief in Tehran

    Return to menu

    An Israeli strike in Tehran killed the intelligence chief of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, the organization said in a statement Sunday, the latest senior military official to be eliminated in Israel’s wide-ranging military campaign.

    Brig. Gen. Mohammad Kazemi was killed along with two other deputies, the statement said, adding that Iran’s barrage of missiles fired at Israel late Sunday was launched in part to avenge his death.

  • Iranian missiles cause damage, injuries in northern and southern Israel

    Return to menu

    Iran launched a barrage of missiles toward Israel on Sunday night, some of which were intercepted while others hit northern Israel, leaving several people with minor injuries. Projectile debris also fell on a residential community near the city of Kiryat Gat in Israel’s south.

  • Return to menu

    Israel on Sunday approved the extension of a nationwide state of emergency until June 30, according to an Israeli official speaking on the condition of anonymity in line with government protocol. Israel’s Home Front Command also announced that school would be canceled and said people should not go to the office or gather together until Tuesday evening.

  • Netanyahu says regime change could be result of Israeli strikes on Iran

    Return to menu

    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that regime change in Iran “could certainly be the result” of Israel’s military campaign.

    Netanyahu made the remarks on “Fox News Sunday” after anchor Bret Baier asked if “regime change” was one of Israel’s objectives. “Clearly, some of these strikes have targeted Iranian leadership, military, nuclear scientists. … So, is regime change part of the effort here?” Baier said.

  • Return to menu

    The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad issued a security alert Sunday saying it was “aware of the increased potential for foreign terrorist organization-inspired violence or attacks against U.S. businesses and locations frequented by U.S. citizens.” The Embassy urged all U.S. citizens in Iraq to avoid such locations and large crowds.

  • Israeli air force struck Iranian aircraft in northeastern Iran, IDF says

    Return to menu

    The Israeli air force struck an Iranian aerial refueling aircraft at Mashhad Airport in northeastern Iran, Israel Defense Forces spokesperson Nadav Shoshani said on X on Sunday.

    Mashhad is a major city that’s almost 1,500 miles from Tel Aviv. Shoshani said the attack was “the longest-range strike conducted since the beginning of the operation.”

  • Return to menu

    Israeli military spokesman Nadav Shoshani said Sunday that Israel’s goal “is not a change of regime” in Iran. He said the objective is to “remove the capabilities of this regime to annihilate us,” including Iran’s nuclear program and arsenal of ballistic missiles.

  • ‘Everyone is really worried,’ Tehran residents feel fear, confusion on third day of strikes

    Return to menu

    Iman, a resident of Tehran, said the city was being hit with strikes on Sunday every 30 minutes to an hour. “The racket and noise is really a lot now,” he said.

    The city was mostly quiet except for people rushing to get needed food and supplies. Gas stations have been packed with people trying to fuel up, and at least some stations were starting to ration fuel to customers.

  • Return to menu

    Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) told CBS News on Sunday that, if diplomacy is not successful, he would urge President Trump to “go all in to make sure that when this operation is over, there’s nothing left standing in Iran regarding their nuclear program."

    “If that means providing bombs ... if it means flying with Israel, fly with Israel,” he said.

  • Return to menu

    Michael Leiter, the Israeli ambassador to the United States, told ABC News on Sunday that Israel’s target list includes anyone “threatening the destruction” of the country. “The idea is to neutralize and terminate the Iranian intention of destroying Israel through nuclear weapons and through ballistic missiles, and anybody who gets in the way of that … is obviously somebody we’re going to have to deal with,” he said.

  • Pence warns Trump against Putin’s advice on Israel-Iran

    Return to menu

    Former vice president Mike Pence warned President Donald Trump on Sunday to steer clear of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s involvement in the response to the Israel-Iran conflict, after Trump and Putin spoke on Saturday.

    “I would say respectfully to the administration, we ought to be looking elsewhere than Vladimir Putin for advice on how to deal with this situation,” Pence said on CNN’s “State of the Union.” Pence was vice president during Trump’s first term.

  • Return to menu

    One Tehran resident said that he told his employees to go home around midday on Sunday, advising them to leave the city, and that most private firms are shutting down. “It’s a total war now,” he said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to avoid government reprisal.

  • Return to menu

    The barrage of strikes hitting Iran and Israel is continuing. Residents in Tehran and Iranian media reported large explosions rocking the capital in the past hour, including in parts of the city center. Within minutes, the Israel Defense Forces warned Israeli citizens to stay near shelters, and sirens alerted in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and northern Israel as the military identified missiles launched from Iran.

  • Return to menu

    Kataib Hezbollah, an Iranian-aligned militant group in Iraq, said Sunday that if Washington “intervenes” in the Israel-Iran conflict, it will target U.S. bases and military assets across the Mideast “without hesitation.” Aside from Yemen’s Houthis, who launched a ballistic missile toward Israel on Saturday “in coordination” with Iranian attacks, Tehran’s proxy forces have not jumped into the fray in the conflict’s initial days.

  • Israel has many targets left to strike in Iran, military official says

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — Israel maintains a large bank of target sites in Iran, an Israeli military official told reporters Sunday, as deadly strikes between the two countries continued into a third day.

    The military official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity in line with military rules, declined to say how many targets remained or to give a timeline for the attacks, as fears grow of a protracted conflict that could risk a wider regional war.

  • Return to menu

    TEL AVIV — Israeli and Iranian airspace will remain closed for a third day, authorities in both countries said, with some flights across the Mideast disrupted because of the risk of a regional conflagration. Israel’s National Security Council has also warned people against returning to Israel via land borders in Egypt and Jordan because of security risks there.

  • Iran doesn’t want conflict to spread ‘unless it is imposed on us,’ top diplomat says

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — If Israeli attacks on Iran stop, “our responses will stop,” Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi told diplomats in a televised briefing Sunday, adding that Tehran doesn’t want strikes to spread to neighboring countries “unless it is imposed on us.”

  • Return to menu

    Iran arrested two people Sunday whom it accused of having ties to the Mossad, Israel’s intelligence agency, in the Alborz province, west of Tehran, the semiofficial Tasnim news agency reported. They were accused of “making bombs, explosives, booby traps and electronic equipment,” the report said, citing a police spokesperson.

  • Return to menu

    Photos show Iran’s Shahran oil depot was engulfed in a massive fireball and plumes of smoke following overnight Israeli strikes on the Iranian capital of Tehran early Sunday.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military issued its first evacuation warning for Iranian civilians nationwide who may be near “military weapons production sites,” now or in the near future, as the region braces for a protracted conflict. The warning, posted on X Sunday morning by a military spokesperson, has routinely signaled in conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon that fresh rounds of Israeli strikes are coming.

  • Return to menu

    Four people were killed Saturday in a rocket strike in northern Israel, according to a local health official and Magen David Adom, Israel’s emergency services. The bodies of two women were found at a destroyed building in the western Galilee region, MDA said. Another woman in critical condition was evacuated from the building but was pronounced dead at a hospital. A fourth woman died at the Rambam medical center in Haifa from injuries sustained during the strike, the center’s spokesman said.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump said on Truth Social that the United States was not involved in Israel’s attacks on Iran overnight, and warned that Iran will face “the full strength and might” of the U.S. military if it attacks the U.S. “in any way.” Trump also said his administration could “easily get a deal done” between Israel and Iran.

  • In ordering major attack on Iran, Netanyahu sheds his inhibitions

    Return to menu

    JERUSALEM — Although the outcome of hostilities that erupted this week between Israel and Iran remains uncertain, the scale and audacity of Israel’s airstrikes have made one thing clear: Inhibitions that may have constrained Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the past no longer do so.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • At least six dead in strike on Bat Yam, Israel, authorities say

    Return to menu

    BAT YAM, Israel — A strike here Sunday killed at least six people and injured dozens more, according to the Israeli prime minister’s office.

    Two women, a boy and a girl were among the dead, Magen David Adom, Israel’s emergency services said in a statement. At least 99 people were injured in the attack, it said, with four in serious condition.

  • U.S. hopes Iran returns to negotiations, U.S. officials say

    Return to menu

    Despite the fighting between Israel and Iran, the United States remains committed to negotiations and hopes Iran “will come to the table soon,” said one senior U.S. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive negotiations.

    That sentiment was echoed in a White House statement calling on Iran to give up its nuclear weapons program.
